Lack of evidence: The expert's verdict states that there is no evidence to support the claim that Katy Perry advised her fans to "add praying to Satan to your bucket list." This lack of evidence raises doubts about the authenticity of the claim.
Source credibility: The expert mentions that the claim originated from Your New Wire, a notorious purveyor of fake news and inventor of ridiculous celebrity quotes. The reputation of the source further undermines the credibility of the claim.
Inconsistencies in the reported event: The expert points out that Katy Perry denied rumors of plastic surgery at the Stella McCartney fashion event in Los Angeles, but there is no mention of her making the controversial comments about praying to Satan. This inconsistency raises questions about the accuracy of the claim.
History of false quotes and hoaxes: The expert highlights that YourNewsWire has a history of concocting false celebrity quotes, including previous false claims about Katy Perry. This pattern of spreading misinformation further casts doubt on the authenticity of the claim.
